tr.td:
Dear Dr. O'Reilly,
Thank you for referring Ms. Critchard to the gastroenterology outpatient clinic.
First attendance face to face
Face-to-face
Dr. Ruth Jones (Consultant Gastroenterologist)
Gastroenterology
Appointment to be made at a later date
Mrs. N Bryant (IBD Specialist Nurse)

td.p: Organisation: Canvas Health Centre, 27 Acacia Road, BM9 6PM

tr.td:
Ms. Critchard presents with ongoing symptoms of bloody diarrhoea, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort that are unresponsive to treatment. She has a 2 month history of bloody diarrhoea. Her bowels open 5-6 per day with 1-2 nocturnal episodes. Ms. Critchard has experienced weight loss of 1 stone over the same period. She experiences a crampy left iliac fossa pain intermittently.
She has no history of travel, unwell contacts or previous similar symptoms. She has longstanding mild dyspepsia for which she takes antacid as necessary. It has never been investigated.
Ms. Critchard has no family history of I.B.D.
Ms. Critchard lives with her boyfriend.
Ms. Critchard works as a Baker.
She is an ex-smoker, stopped 2 years.
She consumed 10-14 units of alcohol per week.
Amoxicillin
Ms. Critchard has an allergic reaction to Amoxicillin, which presents as an urticarial rash in the form of a generalized severe rash.
She first experienced a reaction aged 12 and probability of recurrence is likely.
The abdomen was found to be soft but mainly tender in the left iliac fossa. There was no guarding or rebound and bowel sounds normal.
Facael calprotein levels were 247mcg/g faeces (normal 50)
A Rigid sigmoidoscopy was performed to the limit of view at 20cm. It showed inflamed and ulcerated mucosa with contact bleeding to about 15cm. Proximally appears to improve.
Findings are suggestive of IBD. Rigid sigmoidoscopy looks like UC. 5ASA treatment commenced today pending further investigation.

tr.th: Plan and requested actions for healthcare professionals

tr.td: A flexible sigmoidoscopy has been Requested on an urgent basis by Ruth Jones on 01/05/17. FBC, U and E, LFT and CRP are to be measured, the patient was provided with a form at the appointment. Stool MC and S plus C. diff are to be taken, the patient was given forms and collections points at the appointment.
(only changes to medications and medical devices as a result of the outpatient encounter are included)
Asacol
Oral
3x800mg tablets
Once a day as 3x800mg tablets. A 14xday course was prescribed in clinic.
It is expected that this will aid symptom management.
A 14xday course was prescribed in clinic, please renew in 2xweeks time.
Dr. Ruth Jones
Consultant Gastroenterologist
Gastroenterology

display.value: On examination - left iliac fossa tender
Quantitative measurement of calprotectin in stool specimen

text.value: 2.4mg per day of Asacol in tablet form, to be taken orally once a day as 3x800mg tablets.
